info.game_comments:
2007 College Championship quarterfinal game 1.
From the University of Southern California.

(1, 1).clue: Charles Walgreen Jr. grew up working for his dad in this type of store

(2, 1).clue: You can rest up at the Churchill, Claridge's or the Ivanhoe Suites, hotels in this city

(3, 1).clue: Warren Burger retired from this job in 1986

(4, 1).clue: This branch of medicine is devoted to the care of children & the treatment of their diseases

(5, 1).clue: Specific type of nail-knocker seen here

(6, 1).clue: That spooky woman's head in a crystal ball always freaks me out on this scary ride

(1, 2).clue: With his dad, Robert Stephenson built an engine for these in 1829 that did an amazing 36 mph

(2, 2).clue: Life is a carnival when you travel to this country

(3, 2).clue: Rodin's classic group "The Burghers of" this city is seen here

(4, 2).clue: In 1984 the FDA approved this drug for over-the-counter sales; popular brands include Advil & Motrin

(5, 2).clue: It's from the Dutch for "cabbage salad"

(6, 2).clue: I'll feel like a kid again on this flying elephant ride, a fixture at Disneyland since 1955

(1, 3).clue: Robert McCormick invented a hempbrake, but it was his son Cyrus who came up with this machine

(2, 3).clue: Go sail into this port city, "Kaapstad" in Afrikaans, founded in 1652 by a Dutch official

(3, 3).clue: A burger is a German townsman; a burgermeister is this local authority in a town

(4, 3).clue: In 1893 this Baltimore university became the first major medical school to admit women as well as men

(6, 3).clue: I love the theme of global unity on the ride in which international dolls sing this interminable tune

(1, 4).clue: In the 1880s he turned his dad's floundering San Francisco Examiner newspaper into a profitmaker

(2, 4).clue: You can go visit this "glorious" nation seen here

(3, 4).clue: Hans Berger developed this brain-wave-analyzing device, EEG for short

(4, 4).clue: Using this insect, geneticist Thomas Morgan proved that some traits pass on to only one sex or the other

(5, 4).clue: This river flows 800 miles between the U.S. & Canada

(6, 4).clue: Aaargh!  I can't wait to go on this classic ride now that Captain Jack Sparrow is part of the fun

(1, 5).clue: In the 1500s Andrea Amati & his 2 sons started a dynasty making these musical instruments

(2, 5).clue: Take firth things firth; the Antonine Wall was built across Scotland from the Firth of Clyde to this firth

(3, 5).clue: Berger sings "Donna" in Act 1 of this musical; later, he explains that Claude has to go before the draft board

(4, 5).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew shows a diagram on a monitor.)  In the spinal cord & the brain, these specialized cells consist of an axon, one or more dendrites & a nucleus

(5, 5).clue: Chewa & Ngonde are among the main ethnic groups in this African country

(6, 5).clue: Well, zip-a-dee-doo-dah!  I can't wait to get soaked on this ride that has a 5-story plunge near the end

(1, 1).clue: In James Michener's "Journey", it's 1897 & 5 men are in a rush to find this in the Klondike

(3, 1).clue: From the French for "opening", it's the music played before the opera begins

(4, 1).clue: In 2005 on the "Today" show, this actor told Matt Lauer, "You don't know the history of psychiatry.  I do"

(5, 1).clue: Some of these "activities" you won't be graded on are intramural sports & student government

(6, 1).clue: The three guys seen here are part of a mural painted by this man

(1, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from Bloomsbury Square, London.)  His "Barnaby Rudge", a novel of the 1780 anti-Catholic riots, describes the rioters' actions, & later their hanging, here--in Bloomsbury Square

(3, 2).clue: The "di sortita" type of this solo is sung by a character about to make an exit--sometimes not a moment too soon

(4, 2).clue: On the Aug. 6, 2003 "Tonight Show", he announced "Say hasta la vista to Gray Davis"

(5, 2).clue: You probably wrote this short literary composition as part of your college application

(6, 2).clue: The fresco seen here shows monks practicing martial arts in this country

(1, 3).clue: This Dumas hero is incarcerated for allegedly carrying letters from Elba to Paris

(2, 3).clue: Memphis Raines,Sailor Ripley,Johnny Blaze (aka Ghost Rider)

(3, 3).clue: "I got plenty o' nuttin'"--I'm not complaining, I'm quoting a song from this American opera

(4, 3).clue: Of campaigning with her husband, she said in 2007, "I'm absolutely ready for this... I don't look sickly, I don't feel sickly"

(5, 3).clue: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute has majors in 14 types of this, including aeronautical

(6, 3).clue: The two men seen here have similar last names & share this grand title

(2, 4).clue: Papa Klump,Mama Klump,Ernie Klump,Prof. Sherman Klump

(5, 4).clue: This type of exam, like the SAT, is part of the college admissions requirement

(3, 5).clue: If a big buxom blonde is belting out "rhue, rhue, du Gott!", your're watching this opera that ends the "Ring" cycle

(6, 5).clue: The bug seen here above Anubis' head is one of these beetles
